metadata.case_name: Cement Manufacturing Company & Directors v. Central Government

facts.text: First petitioner is a company carrying on business in the manufacture of cement in the State of Orissa and petitioners Nos. 2 and 3 are two of its Directors.

Petitioners filed petition under Art. 32 challenging validity of notifications dated January 15, 1958, and December 2, 1960, issued by Central Government under s. 7(1) of the Employees' Provident Funds Act, 1952.
Employees' Provident Funds Act, 1952 passed for institution of Provident Funds for employees in factories and other establishments.
Section 5(1) empowers Central Government to frame Scheme by notification specifying establishments to which it applies.
Section 6(1) requires employer contribution of 6.25% of basic wages, dearness allowance and retaining allowance; employee contribution equal.
Section 7 empowers Central Government to add to, amend or vary any Scheme.
Section 14 prescribes penalties for contravention or default.
Employees' Provident Funds Scheme, 1952 published September 2, 1952.
Para 2(f)(iii) of 1952 Scheme defines excluded employees as those employed by or through a contractor.
Para 26 requires employees (other than excluded) with one year's continuous service (or 240 days) to become members.
Paras 30-32: Employer pays both contributions initially, deducts employee's share from wages.
Employers resorted to contract labour to avoid contributions.

Notification No. S.R.O. 331 dated January 15, 1958 amended Para 2(f)(iii) to exclude only employees by contractor in operations not directly connected with manufacturing process; principal employer responsible for compliance.
Para 26 amended May 11, 1959 to conform to 1958 notification.
Notification No. G.S.R. 1467 dated December 2, 1960 repealed Para 2(f)(iii) and added Para 73A making principal employer responsible for all contractor employees.
Authorities issued notices to first petitioner to comply; management replied citing practical difficulties; long correspondence culminated in threat of penal proceedings under s.14.

legal_issues.text: Whether notifications dated January 15, 1958 and December 2, 1960 are valid or impose unreasonable restrictions on trade under Art. 19(1)(g) not saved by Art. 19(6).
Whether extension of 1952 Scheme to contract labour without adjustment leads to unjust results.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notifications throw heavy burden on business, unreasonable restriction under Art. 19(6), infringe Art. 19(1)(g).
Principal employer cannot know wages paid by contractor, cannot maintain muster rolls for contract labour, cannot ascertain continuous service for Para 26.
Cannot deduct employee's share under Para 32 as not paying wages directly to contract labour.

respondent_arguments.text: Notifications are beneficent legislation in interests of public, within Art. 19(6).
Principal employer can arrange with contractor to deduct from amounts payable to contractor or sue under s.69 Contract Act.

court_reasoning.text: Notifications conceived in public interest to remove discrimination against contract labour.
Difficulties in knowing wages/service can be overcome by requiring particulars from contractor.
Para 32 deduction right inapplicable to contract labour as principal employer does not pay their wages; leads to principal employer bearing full contribution without recoupment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme operates unfairly, harshly, discriminatorily between direct and contract labour employers.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent suggestions (arrangement with contractor or suit) inadequate as Para 32 mandates deduction from wages only, no obligation on contractor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Breaks legislative intent in s.6(1) for equal sharing.

holdings.text: Notifications dated January 15, 1958, and December 2, 1960, are unconstitutional and void as not reasonable under Art. 19(6).

statutes_cited.name: Employees' Provident Funds Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers framing/amending Scheme; contribution obligations; penalties. Scheme provisions applied unfairly to contract labour.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petition; test for reasonable restrictions on trade.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned by respondents for recovery, but held inadequate.

outcome.summary: Court held notifications dated January 15, 1958, and December 2, 1960, unconstitutional and void for imposing unreasonable burden on principal employers regarding contract labour provident fund contributions.

key_quotes.text: The Scheme therefore cannot be said to be reasonable and must be struck down as not falling within the protection afforded by Art. 19(6).
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It operates unfairly and harshly on persons who employ contract labour and it further results in discrimination between those who employ contract labour and those who employ direct labour.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why Scheme invalid for contract labour.
